title: How to Cut Celery

steps.headline: Separate the celery stalks from one another.
steps.description: To separate the stalks, grab a stalk and gently pull it from the bottom until it snaps off. Repeat this process until all of the stalks have been separated. Separating the stalks will make cutting them much easier.

steps.headline: Wash and trim the stalks.
steps.description: After the stalks have been pulled apart, wash each one with clean running water. This will help remove any dirt on the celery.

steps.headline: Trim the stalks using a knife.
steps.description: Remove the white sections of each stalk by cutting them off with a knife. You want to be left with an all-green stalk.

steps.headline: Peel the stalks if desired.
steps.description: If  you want to get rid of the course strings in the outer layer of the celery, you can peel them. Use a vegetable peeler to peel off the outer layer of each stalk, being careful to use the peeler safely. You can also make a little cut into the top of each stalk and then break it off, which should allow you to pull down the length of the stalk and remove the strings. Hold the bottom of the stalk firmly if using a vegetable peeler and peel in controlled, smooth motions.

steps.headline: Split the celery into long pieces for a snack.
steps.description: Cut your celery into snack-like pieces by slicing each stalk down the middle lengthwise. Then you can chop up the 2 halves into 3–4 inch (7.6–10 cm) pieces, choosing how long you want each celery stick to be. You can also skip the lengthwise cut, leaving the celery in its half moon form. This is perfect for holding your favorite spread, such as peanut butter, in the middle.

steps.headline: Chop the stalks into large chunks for stocks, sauces, and stews.
steps.description: Using a sharp knife, cut the celery stalks into pieces that are 1 to 1.5 inches (2.5 to 3.8 cm). Stop cutting when you reach the joint that connects to the leaves.

steps.headline: Cut the celery into thin slices for salads or sautées.
steps.description: Cut the celery into small slices so that they resemble half moons. Most slices will be ⁄8 to ⁄4 inch (0.32 to 0.64 cm) thick. If you want larger half moons, you can cut the celery at an angle. This creates slices that are longer but just as thin.

steps.headline: Create celery batons to use in soups and salads.
steps.description: Cut the stalk lengthwise into 2 or 3 even strips. Then cut each strip into sections that are 1.5 to 2 inches (3.8 to 5.1 cm) long so that the celery pieces resemble batons, or tiny sticks.

steps.headline: Dice the stalk finely for the smallest cut.
steps.description: Split each stalk into 2-4 sections lengthwise, so that you form long, skinny pieces. Keep one end of the stalk attached to the base/root/end in order to chop faster. Begin cutting up the celery crosswise, finely dicing the stalks to your desired size. Splitting the stalk down the middle before dicing will create fine dice, while splitting the stalk into 4 pieces will form incredibly fine dice.

Repeat this process until all of the stalks have been separated. Separating the stalks will make cutting them much easier. Wash and trim the stalks. You can also make a little cut into the top of each stalk and then break it off, which should allow you to pull down the length of the stalk and remove the strings. Hold the bottom of the stalk firmly if using a vegetable peeler and peel in controlled, smooth motions. Choosing a Cutting Tactic Split the celery into long pieces for a snack. Cut your celery into snack-like pieces by slicing each stalk down the middle lengthwise. Then you can chop up the 2 halves into 3–4 inch (7.6–10 cm) pieces, choosing how long you want each celery stick to be. You can also skip the lengthwise cut, leaving the celery in its half moon form. This is perfect for holding your favorite spread, such as peanut butter, in the middle. Chop the stalks into large chunks for stocks, sauces, and stews. Using a sharp knife, cut the celery stalks into pieces that are 1 to 1.5 inches (2.5 to 3.8 cm). Stop cutting when you reach the joint that connects to the leaves. Cut the celery into thin slices for salads or sautées. Cut the celery into small slices so that they resemble half moons. Most slices will be ⁄8 to ⁄4 inch (0.32 to 0.64 cm) thick. If you want larger half moons, you can cut the celery at an angle. This creates slices that are longer but just as thin. Create celery batons to use in soups and salads. Cut the stalk lengthwise into 2 or 3 even strips. Then cut each strip into sections that are 1.5 to 2 inches (3.8 to 5.1 cm) long so that the celery pieces resemble batons, or tiny sticks. Dice the stalk finely for the smallest cut. Split each stalk into 2-4 sections lengthwise, so that you form long, skinny pieces. Keep one end of the stalk attached to the base/root/end in order to chop faster. Begin cutting up the celery crosswise, finely dicing the stalks to your desired size. Splitting the stalk down the middle before dicing will create fine dice, while splitting the stalk into 4 pieces will form incredibly fine dice. Finished.
